comments.commentBody:
Americans want universal care the way they wanted Obamacare before they actually saw its constraints and actually had to pay for it.

As long as universal care works exactly as they want it to work (ex., little or no cost to them, access to doctors, short wait times, etc.), they want it.

The catch is that it has to remain in the future to maintain its desirability.

Yes, mnh, I did rather hog the limelight with this scintillating XWDP, courtesy of the team of K. Walker and D. Quarfoot, and for that I make no apologies, as it was a Classic Cruciverbalistic CARNIVAL!

Howie

Fracking is really all about prices above $70/bl, and the technological improvements have been pretty impressive.  The breakeven number might be $50/bl is a few years.  Not that I'm a fan of this development.  Cheaper fossil fuels make the threat to this planet from global warming all the more pressing.

So we're back to producing as much o'l as we were about 1960 on the upswing and about 1990 on the downslope. What is the consumption multiplier between 2014 and 1960? 10x? Too big? 2x? (I looked it up - it's about 2x - not nearly as dramatic). So yes, production is up but so is consumption ... and consumption still far outpaces production. I don't see that as being "significant sized".

Fracking is all about $100/bbl price which makes it worth the investment to recover "unconventional" oil like the stuff locked in shale or that horrible sludge from Alberta. Now the price is probably below the cost of production and production of that stuff will slow or stop now.
Loved the consistent difficulty.  A good time.

Thanks for the compliment but I think it's only fair to point out in Ferguson's defense that it is a small town with a majority black population (and further distinguished by being in a southern state).  The NYC-area is extraordinarily diverse racially and culturally and has long been a beacon for the liberal and open-minded.

The population of Ferguson is mostly black and the population of NYC is extremely diverse, which is something no one can say about anywhere in Canada except First Nation.  These are local populations that are protesting the institutional racism and brutality of the police state, not people shipped in for show.
As a Canadian I notice from the pictures that the protesters seemed to be almost all black in Ferguson, in New York the crowd seems very mixed. I say: good for you New York.

But they didn't focus on health insurance at the expense of focusing on the economy.

How can people simply not remember this?

Anyone who says this is the case is simply blindly restating the GOP talking point myths, so they don't have to try to explain to the public he facts and what really happened. It is easier to work with a popular misconception than to try to undo it.

The GOP created this myth to hide the fact that they filibustered all attempts to help the economy. Even the stimulus required 3 Republican votes to overcome a filibuster

The stimulus passed just a few months into Obama's presidency. As it began to take effect, the ACA was being debated and was signed into law about a year after the stimulus. The auto industry was also bailed out. The free-fall of the economy had been stopped, but they did not know how well the stimulus would fill in the huge gap left by the collapse. The stimulus had partially filled in huge state budget holes caused by lost revenue. Many states would have not been able to accomplish basic functions without it, but it did not cover all revenue losses. Hundreds of thousands of public sector jobs were lost at state and local levels. The Democrats created a huge jobs bill to address this, which included money to rehire teachers & first responders, a jobs program for veterans & money for infrastructure, but the GOP filibustered it. The GOP engaged in more filibusters in Obama's first 2 years than in all of the Senate's history combined.

it's required under ny law for felony charges
i am 100% positive the individual cop and the city of ny will be sued

Unfortunately it would appear that most of them prefer to be feared, rather than respected.  Gangs of bullies who control and get their way with intimidation, violence, and coercion are generally prosecuted, unless they have a badge.
i am certain that unselfish people understand and do not mind

Funny, I felt the same way in 2004 when the same Democrats who voted to support the Iraq war in 2002 turned hard against the war and President Bush.  With Americans like that, we didn't need any enemies.

@YM,
Because Democrats and others outside the hermetically sealed Fox News bubble found out they were duped about Iraq's WMDs and the woefully inadequate estimate of the cost in American blood and treasure of Bush's adventure, not to mention the length of the campaign in months which turned into years.

The "all-American" anti-Obama Republicans have become favorites of al-Qaeda for their Benghazi hysteria, Iranian hardliners for their persistent sabotage of the nuclear talks, Russian nationalists for their worship of Putin's "manliness," and even British royalists for their idolatry of a Churchill bust. (Ironically, it was British journalists, including BBC's Katty Kay, who dismissed Obama's inauguration, declaring it "not a coronation.")

With Americans like these, America has no need for enemies. No enemy can hope to inflict as much damage.

The President did focus on the economy, it was the stimulus package (which the Republicans have gotten the American Public to believe was a failure). At the end of the Bush Administration the Democrats saved the Bush Administration when the financial system was on it's dead bed.
What Schumer should have done was role back the Bush Tax Cuts (and the Reagan Tax Cuts) to raise money for infrastructure expenditures, raised the Gasoline Tax to fix the interstate system along with the decrepit bridges and closed the tax loopholes allowing US Corporation to escape taxation.
He did nothing.

The Southern GOP (well, all the GOP) is built on race fear. If someone tells you it's also a bible belt thing in the South, point out that the evangelical movement's mega churches didn't exist until Southerners needed a church big enough to support private schools to replace the public schools as they were becoming integrated. A lot of people's self worth is tied up in the success of their college football team and the fact that, no matter how poor their healthcare, education or incomes are, their race gives them value.

John, just reading that article made me angry once again. You are right: What else can that attitude be, but racist. All the blockades the Republicans have thrown in the President's path are nothing else but elements used to keep the first Black President from being as successful as he could be. I find him a very welcome change from all the folksy characters that have been in the White house over the past decades. Folksy may be great if you are having a party, but is no good if you want to lead a country.

I never saw that horrendous cartoon you mentioned in your letter, but found and downloaded some otheres I presented to my advanced-level English class. They were horrified at the meanness and the racial hatred reflected in them.

We have five parties that are often at odds with each other, but if there is a problem, they work out solutions, argue bitterly about them, yet always arrive at a consensus everybody can accept - if, at times, grudgingly. Many of us watched developments in the USA with disbelief when the Republicans nearly brought government to a standstill because they refused to raise the debt ceiling.

What in the world has happened to America which, abroad, preaches respect for all people, regrdless of race, religion or national heritage?

Conservatives aren't sorry about racist statements made about Barack for the simple reason they don't want to alienate voters they otherwise know will vote for them. In other words, they are willing to compromise themselves morally to get power, believe the statements, or both.

Look at the history:
1. Speaker Boehner refused Barack a speech date request, the first time a President was refused a request.

2. Marilyn Davenport sent fellow Republicans an email depicting President Obama as a chimpanzee, in the arms of chimpanzee “parents." She added, “Now you know why no birth certificate. She said the media made too much of it.

3. Republicans and the like minded established a new style ordering the President around, literally. Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer put her finger in the President’s face.

4. Donald Trump was invited by media outlets to demand that the President “show him his papers."

5. Congressman Joe Walsh went onto a national broadcast to declare he wouldn't attend a Presidential speech.

6. Newt Gingrich described Barack as having “Kenyan anti-colonial behavior”

7. Sarah Palin said Barack behaved like a foreigner and an alien.

8. The Tea Party controlled House refused to raise the debt ceiling despite the fact the debt ceiling was raised 69 times since 1962, 7 times under GW, and 18 times for Reagan.

9. Mitch McConnell announced that his #1 Priority was "...to deny President Obama a second term.

It didn't have to be that way; Republicans encouraged it.
.

In my opinion,The "insensitive attitude" of white cops towards women and minorities may form the basis of and culminates in transgressions like in the Garner case. The disabled community is included in this bias and insensitivity. This insensitive attitude is at work from inner cities to suburbs
across America, richest to poorest, including but not limited to upper crust Bergen County, NJ. This is based on first hand recent experiences.
Bravo Irlo, you are 100% correct. We're getting close to the time when these 'brave' protestors are gong to end up in jail cells, with criminal records and legal bills.

I think, in truth they new that the stimulus was too small. Christine Romer as much made the case inside the admininstration, but it was rejected as a result of political calculus, a calculus made without Obama having to make any political investments, cracking of the whip, or use of the bully pulpit. They made no effort to pursue a real stimulus.

South Korea did. They passed a stimulus equal to 25% of GNP over a 4 year period. They (and Australia) were the only developed nation to register growth in 2009. In early 2010 they had 7% growth and 3% unemployment and the local press refered to the recession of 2009 as ancient history. The same scale of stimulus would have been $4 trillion over 4 years. Anything less than a trillion wasn't serious. On top of that about 45% of the stimulus was in tax breaks - a contributing factor to the cause of the crisis. Nevertheless, it reversed the collapsing trend in employment - the famous bikini curve. But growth in employment took more than a year to return. By that time millions of lives had been irreparably harmed.

The problem with the stimulus, in some degree is similar with the problem with the ACA:

Obama negotiated against himself even before real debate and bargaining began. His campaign for public option was thrown under the bus, as was single payer.

A characteristic of Obama's administration is he campaigns well for his own job, but phones it in for others. He truly fights for little other than his own job.

They had to get 3 Republicans to pass the stimulus. I am proud of Specter, Collins, and Snowe for having the courage to vote for it, but to get their votes, some cuts to the stimulus plan had to be made. Still, they knew passage was essential and did what they could. They knew it might be too small, but there was nothing more they could do at that time to win the needed votes. I don't think they ever conceived at that time that the GOP would filibuster as much as they did when we were in such a huge crisis. I think they thought they could pass more legislation after this, if it proved insufficient.

Obama could have gone out on the road and campaigned for a bigger stimulus. I hate to say it, but George Bush had no qualms on putting pressure on members of commerce by going on the road and campaigning for what he wanted in the districts of members opposing him. I think the threat of this is what got many Democrats to vote for invading Iraq - they couldn't overcome a full force offensive by the executive.

Obama never tried that. Never even bothered considering doing that. I would argue his skills in campaigning were significantly better than Bush but Obama rarely used those skills unless it directly affected his own employment status.

A bigger stimulus would have made the 2010 election come out better and perhaps given Obama a better presidency. He really only had 2 years to rule.

I am sorry that there are not more Specters in congress.

Obama didn't focus on health insurance at the expense of focusing on the economy.

How can people simply not remember this?

Anyone who says this is the case is simply blindly restating the GOP talking points.

The GOP created this myth to hide the fact that they filibustered all attempts to help the economy. Even the stimulus required 3 Republican votes to overcome a filibuster

The stimulus passed just a few months into Obama's presidency. As it began to take effect, the ACA was being debated and was signed into law about a year after the stimulus. The auto industry was also bailed out. The free-fall of the economy had been stopped, but they did not know how well the stimulus would fill in the huge gap left by the collapse. The stimulus had partially filled in huge state budget holes caused by lost revenue. Many states would have not been able to accomplish basic functions without it, but it did not cover all revenue losses. Hundreds of thousands of public sector jobs were lost at state and local levels. The Democrats created a huge jobs bill to address this, which included money to rehire teachers & first responders, a jobs program for veterans & money for infrastructure, but the GOP filibustered it. The GOP engaged in more filibusters in Obama's first 2 years than in all of the Senate's history combined.

Funny how things in the South have inverted. It's not the reversal of allegiances to the parties that's strange, as neither party resembles what it was 50 or 100 years ago, but the reversed roles of blacks and whites. Ralph Ellison wrote about the choir singing songs that the white visitors loved and that the choir came to love, too, "as the defeated come to love the symbols of their conquerors." Now it's the African-Americans who decline to sing for the powerful and the whites who take up the melodies of those who patronize and impoverish them. I guess that's a form of  progress.

Until officials like Ms. Falque-Pierrotin require that the newspapers whose articles Google links to must also remove the supposedly privacy-invading material, the whole argument smacks of hypocrisy. This case began when a Spanish businessman wanted to have embarrassing material about his past that was published in a Spanish newspaper become invsible to Google searches. I didn't see the EU telling the newspaper to delete the story from its archives; only big, bad, and worst of all American, Google was held to be at fault.

The commercial Internet has existed for two decades now. How many of the globally well-known Internet brands are based in Europe? Shouldn't the EU focus its attention on the failure of its member countries to keep pace with the most important technological advance in decades rather than trying to restrict American competitors?

Plus Ca Change-
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7fgB0m_y2I
NYC is a very heavily populated and busy city.  Protestors who block traffic need to understand that they are likely to be arrested and being held in an NYC jail is not a pleasant experience.
Noisy protesters at night are likely to be arrested by cops who will undoubtedly not be pleased with them.

The problem with Obamacare as a public policy has been, all along, that Obama has not been willing or able to formulate a concise, punchy way of stating the value and efficacy of the policy. Instead, he (and the Democrats, including Schumer) have let the Republicans define the Affordable Care Act in as negative light as possible. I suspect this is because the sprawling bill that was enacted seemed too much an unwieldy sum of its parts. But Obama completely blew it by not adopting a slogan and a punch list of four salient positives to make his point. And the Democrats in Congress blew it because they had ample evidence that the legislation was working after its awful start but let themselves be cornered by the Republicans. When it comes to reaping the justifiable rewards of putting into law good policy, Obama and the Democrats have been their worst enemies.

Apparently you don't recall how the negotiation with Rs went before the vote. Everything they wanted, they got, but in the end, their obstruction tactic made them vote against what was originally an R plan ... known prior to the ACA as Romneycare.

@Tim: come on. Stop trying to put lipstick on that pig.

Mr. Obama could have said, "You can keep your old insurance, IF it complies with the new ACA rules". If that was what he meant.

But it is NOT what he SAID. He said "if you LIKE it".

YOU don't get to tell other people what THEY like or want or need.

Note: a mandate to buy insurance from a private for-profit corporation is NOT a requirement to have health care -- in fact, no other nation has anything whatsoever like this.

AACNY -- not so nice a try.  Health insurance changes all the time.  It was clear that he meant that things wouldn't change much compared to what they were before the ACA wrt people who already had health insurance.  No one EVER got to "keep" their health insurance in the way you now imagine Obama was saying people would be able to.  But most of us (including me) got to "keep" our health insurance in the way we've been "keeping" it (me for 27 years) in the past.  There really were no serious surprises here.

There are many reasons why the A.C.A left a bad taste for most Americans.

1 - It is the first time since the civil war that a major restructuring and regulation of an entire large sector of the US economy was done with total disregard, and without a single vote from the opposing party. Social Security and Medicare, in contrast, had decent bi-partizan support.

2 - The law is so complex, that major portions of it, like the employer mandate, had to be postponed, because even the President was unsure of the consequences to the economy. Conveniently, they have all been postponed to after the elections.

3 - The President was caught on a flat out lie. "If you like your plan you can keep it", except you can't.

4 - The implementation was disastrous. After years of preparation it didn't work. The head of the agency in charge had to be fired.

5 - Lots of people with good coverage were inconvenienced and had their plans cancelled. You don't fix something, by breaking the parts that are working.

6 - Massive tax increases to pay for it. 3.8% additional tax on investment income, medical device tax, medicare surtax, etc, etc.

7 - Americans, for the first time ever, were forced to buy a commercial product (insurance) by the Federal Government.

It is a big list of negatives, to cover an additional 7% of the US population.

It could have been done in a much better way, like simply offering incentives to the states to come up with their own Massachusetts-style plans.
Used in musical notation.

WVC, Evidently, the Ne Plus Ultra of languages isn't dead in the northern reaches of Canada? LOL

Howie

Leapy

Knew enough long answers to help get the answers of which I was unsure which filled in those I didn't know at all, including OSCINE. What is BIS for encore? Fave clue was "Furry oyster cracker". Enjoyed doing this one; thought the cluing was well done.
You are obviously unaware that exchange-quality plans existed before the advent of the federal exchange.  The term, "cadillac plans", is one name for them.
AACNY, you need to work on your reading comprehension skills. Vashti4 didn't say there weren't real "exchange-quality" plans prior to the ACA. Try again.

Here's another good thing that Obamacare has accomplished, prior to the ACA up to 50 million Americans had essentially bogus health insurance. They paid premiums, but if they needed health care, their policies paid just about zip. The ACA has pretty much put an end to that particular scam.
